sections.heading: SECTION 1 — INTRODUCTION
sections.content:
1.1 Purpose of HVAC Optimization Modeling This manual provides the full engineering logic for understanding, classifying, modeling, and optimizing HVAC systems for commercial buildings. It enables AI to behave like a senior HVAC controls engineer, an energy modeler, a building simulation expert, and a utility program reviewer simultaneously.

It allows the system to: Identify HVAC systems from incomplete data Model HVAC load profiles Estimate baseline and proposed energy usage Calculate realistic kWh and therms savings Predict interactions between HVAC changes and whole-building loads Recommend measures based on physics Avoid unrealistic savings Explain results to non-engineers Select correct energy efficiency measures (EEMs) Apply them in multi-measure optimizations Integrate with battery and DR modeling

1.2 Scope This manual covers: Commercial HVAC system identification Building thermal modeling Cooling and heating load estimation Fan and pump energy modeling Chiller and boiler modeling VAV, VVT, CAV, RTU, AHU, CHW plant logic Airflow modeling Coil performance HVAC controls sequences Advanced reset strategies Fault detection logic HVAC efficiency measure calculations Therms-to-kWh interactions Multi-measure interactions

It excludes industrial process cooling unless indirectly related.

1.3 AI Behavioral Requirements AI must follow these rules: Never hallucinate HVAC systems Never assume savings without validated physics Always classify systems before modeling Use load shapes + building type to infer HVAC type Use conservative estimates if data missing Reject measures incompatible with system type Always explain why a measure is (or is not) viable Always state uncertainty Always run technical constraints checks Never double count cooling + heating savings Never apply chiller EEMs to RTU-only buildings

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 2 — IDENTIFYING HVAC SYSTEM TYPE
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

2.1 Primary HVAC System Categories AI must classify HVAC systems into one of the following major categories:

Category A — Packaged RTUs (common in: retail, schools, warehouses) Category B — Split Heat Pumps (smaller offices, small commercial) Category C — VRF / VRV Heat Pump Systems Category D — VAV with Central AHU + CHW Plant Category E — VAV with Central AHU + DX Cooling + Boiler Heating Category F — CAV with CHW/Boiler Category G — Multi-zone Units Category H — Industrial DX Systems Category I — Hydronic Heating (boilers + pumps + coils)

2.2 Identification Inputs AI must identify HVAC type using: Building type (hospital, school, office, retail, lab) Square footage Electric load profile Gas usage profile Seasonal consumption ratios Operating schedule Presence of boiler usage in winter Presence of chilled water

2.3 Identification Logic Examples Hospitals → Almost always CHW plant + boiler Large offices → VAV system with AHU, CHW or DX Small offices → Heat pumps or RTUs Schools → RTUs + boilers Warehouses → Minimal HVAC, unit heaters Labs → VAV with CHW, fume hood exhaust Retail → RTUs with economizers

2.4 Interval Data Signatures AI must read interval patterns:

Cooling-dominant building: Sharp summer afternoon peaks Limited winter activity

Heating-dominant building: High winter mornings Lower summer usage

Mixed-mode: Both summer afternoon peaks and winter morning spikes

Process-heavy: Flat year-round baseload Little correlation with weather

2.5 Gas Consumption Signatures If gas usage spikes in winter → boiler-based system If gas usage is minimal → likely RTUs or heat pumps If gas usage is huge year-round → process load, not HVAC

2.6 Sizing Inference Small buildings (<30k sq ft): RTUs or split systems Medium buildings (30–150k sq ft): VAV, packaged DX Large (>150k sq ft): Central plant (chillers + boilers)

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 3 — BUILDING THERMODYNAMICS
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

3.1 Overview Cooling and heating loads depend on building physics. AI must compute approximate loads from weather, envelope properties, internal loads, and ventilation.

3.2 Building Cooling Load Components Sensible internal gains: Lights Equipment Occupants

sections.heading: Latent internal gains: Occupant humidity Process moisture
sections.content:
Envelope gains: Solar radiation Conduction through walls/roof Infiltration

3.3 Building Heating Load Components Conduction losses Ventilation heating Infiltration heating Reheat in VAV systems

3.4 Cooling Degree Hour Model Cooling load is proportional to temperature difference above cooling balance point.

CoolingBalancePoint ≈ 55°F for commercial buildings CoolingLoad ∝ Σ(max(0, Temperature − CoolingBalancePoint))

AI must compute CDH if weather data available.

3.5 Heating Degree Hour Model HeatingBalancePoint ≈ 60–65°F HeatingLoad ∝ Σ(max(0, HeatingBalancePoint − Temperature))

AI must compute HDH for therm savings prediction.

3.6 Internal Load Estimation AI must use building type to infer typical internal loads:

Office: 0.75–1.25 W/sqft lighting 1.0–2.5 W/sqft plug load 250–500 BTU/hr per occupant

sections.heading: Retail: High lighting load High occupant diversity High door traffic
sections.content:
3.7 Ventilation Requirements AI must enforce minimum ventilation per ASHRAE 62.1 when estimating load.

Ventilation load = cfm_ventilation × (Temp_outdoor − Temp_indoor) × 1.08

3.8 Infiltration Infiltration = ACH × Volume × 0.018 BTU/hr-F

AI must apply infiltration loads conservatively.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 4 — HVAC BASELINE ENERGY MODELING
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

4.1 Baseline Energy Components HVAC baseline includes:

Cooling kWh Heating therms Fan kWh Pump kWh Reheat kWh/therms Economizer effect Ventilation loads

AI must compute approximate baseline energy distribution.

4.2 Cooling Energy Model CoolingEnergy = CoolingLoad / CoolingSystem_EER

Where EER = energy efficiency ratio.

Typical values: Old RTUs: EER 8–10 Modern RTUs: EER 12–14 Chillers: COP 4–6 (convert to EER by multiplying by 3.412)

4.3 Heating Energy Model HeatingEnergyTherms = HeatingLoad / BoilerEfficiency

BoilerEfficiency: Old boiler: 70–80% Modern condensing: 90–95%

4.4 Fan Energy Model FanPower ∝ Flow^3 FanEnergy = FanPower × OperatingHours

If VAV with static pressure reset applied → significant reduction possible.

4.5 Pump Energy Model PumpPower ∝ Flow^3 PumpEnergy = PumpPower × OperatingHours

4.6 Reheat Load In VAV systems, reheating occurs after chilled air is delivered.

ReheatEnergyTherms = ReheatLoad / BoilerEfficiency

sections.heading: ReheatLoad depends on: Supply air temperature Minimum airflow setpoints Occupancy load
SECTION 5 — HVAC OPTIMIZATION MEASURES (OVERVIEW)
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

5.1 Categories of HVAC EEMs This manual covers detailed modeling for:

Air-side measures: Supply Air Temperature (SAT) Reset Static Pressure Reset Demand-Controlled Ventilation (CO2/DCV) Economizer optimization AHU scheduling Fan VFDs

Water-side measures: Chilled water reset Condenser water reset Pump VFDs Cooling tower optimization Boiler reset

Equipment replacement measures: RTU replacement Chiller replacement Boiler replacement Heat pump retrofit

Commissioning measures: Sensor calibration Control sequence correction AHU tune-up

AI must understand when each measure applies based on system type.

5.2 Measure Interactions Some measures interact: SAT reset reduces reheat Reheat reduction reduces heating therms CHW reset reduces chiller kWh but may reduce dehumidification Economizer increases ventilation load

AI must avoid double-counting savings.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 6 — VAV SYSTEM ENGINEERING (VARIABLE AIR VOLUME)
sections.content:
6.1 VAV System Overview A VAV system supplies conditioned air at a relatively constant supply air temperature (typically 55°F) and varies airflow to control space temperature. VAV is the most common HVAC system in offices, hospitals, schools, and commercial buildings > 30,000 sq ft.

Components: Central AHU (Air Handling Unit) VAV terminal boxes Reheat coils Primary cooling coil Fans (supply and sometimes return) Duct static pressure sensors Economizer dampers

6.2 VAV Operating Principle Supply air temperature is usually fixed (55°F), while terminal boxes modulate damper position to deliver more or less airflow. Fan speed modulates based on duct static pressure.

6.3 VAV Equations ZoneLoad = cfm_zone × 1.08 × (SAT − SpaceTemp)

Where: cfm_zone = airflow delivered to zone SAT = supply air temperature 1.08 = constant (air density × specific heat × minutes)

6.4 VAV Fan Power FanPower ∝ Flow^3

If airflow reduced by 20%: Power drops by (0.8)^3 = 0.512 (≈ 50% reduction)

6.5 VAV Reheat ReheatLoad = cfm_min × 1.08 × (SpaceTemp − SAT)

Where cfm_min is minimum airflow required by ASHRAE or system needs.

6.6 VAV Savings Mechanisms Resetting SAT reduces reheat therms. Resetting static pressure reduces fan power. Ventilation tuning reduces cooling and heating load. Better scheduling reduces fan run hours.

6.7 AI must determine baseline: Minimum airflow ratio (typical 30% of design) Duct static pressure setpoint (e.g., 1.5” wc) SAT setpoint (e.g., 55°F) Operating schedule

6.8 VAV Optimization Savings FanSavings_VAV = BaselineFanPower − NewFanPower Where NewFanPower = BaselineFanPower × (SP_new/SP_old)^(3/2)

ReheatSavings_VAV = BaselineReheat − NewReheat

SATResetSavings ≈ 5–15% cooling reduction StaticPressureResetSavings ≈ 10–30% fan reduction

sections.heading: SECTION 7 — VVT SYSTEM ENGINEERING (VARIABLE VOLUME/VARIABLE TEMPERATURE)
sections.content:
7.1 Overview VVT blends aspects of VAV with multi-zone packaged systems. It changes both airflow and supply air temperature but is less efficient than VAV.

7.2 Identification Common in: Schools Small commercial Low-rise offices

7.3 VVT Savings Approaches Improved scheduling Improved thermostat control SAT reset Fan VFD retrofit

7.4 VVT Reheat Interaction Less common than VAV, but similar principles apply.

7.5 Equations similar to VAV but with: More abrupt cycling Less precise fan control Higher minimum ventilation

AI must apply VVT savings conservatively: 5–12%.

sections.heading: SECTION 8 — CAV SYSTEM ENGINEERING (CONSTANT AIR VOLUME)
sections.content:
8.1 Overview CAV delivers constant airflow regardless of load. Temperature is modulated by varying supply air temperature.

8.2 Identification Common in older hospitals and schools.

8.3 Inefficiency Sources Constant high fan power High reheat energy Poor part-load performance

8.4 Savings Convert to VAV (rarely done in retrofits) Reset SAT Reduce airflow Install VFD retrofits

8.5 CAV Savings Estimates FanSavings_CAV = (1 − (Flow_new/Flow_old)^3)

ReheatSavings_CAV higher than VAV due to constant airflow.

AI must apply strict feasibility checks—fan retuning on CAV is delicate.

sections.heading: SECTION 9 — RTU ENGINEERING (ROOFTOP UNITS)
sections.content:
9.1 Overview RTUs are packaged HVAC units found on most small–medium commercial buildings. They contain: Compressor Evaporator Condenser Economizer Supply fan (constant or multi-speed)

9.2 RTU Efficiency EER (Energy Efficiency Ratio) typical values: Old RTU: 8–10 New high-efficiency RTU: 12–16 Heat pump RTU COP: 2.5–3.5

9.3 RTU Optimization Measures Economizer repair ECM fan retrofit VFD fan retrofit** (if supported) Advanced controls retrofit (add-on economizer control, supply air reset) Staging optimization RTU replacement

9.4 RTU Cooling Load CoolingEnergy_RTU = CoolingLoad / EER

9.5 RTU Heating Load GasHeating_RTUs use: HeatingEnergyTherms = HeatingLoad / FurnaceEfficiency

9.6 RTU Economizer Savings EconomizerSavings = PercentOfHours_OA_OK × CoolingLoad × EconomizerEfficiencyFactor

AI must compute OA conditions from climate zone or weather file.

9.7 RTU Fan Savings FanSaving = BaselineFanPower − NewFanPower Use: FanPower ∝ Speed^3

sections.heading: SECTION 10 — FAN LAWS & AIRFLOW PHYSICS (EXTENDED DETAIL)
sections.content:
10.1 Fan Laws Three fundamental laws:

Flow ∝ Speed Pressure ∝ Speed^2 Power ∝ Speed^3

10.2 Static Pressure Reset Fan speed modulates to maintain duct pressure. Savings formula: Savings = 1 − (SP_new/SP_old)^(3/2)

10.3 Fan Efficiency Curve Fan efficiency varies with: Blade shape Static pressure Flow fraction

If Flow < 40% of design, efficiency collapses.

AI must not overestimate fan VFD savings at low load.

10.4 Motor Efficiency MotorEff = OutputPower / InputPower

AI must apply motor and VFD efficiency correction.

10.5 Fan Power Calculation FanPower = Flow × Pressure / Efficiency

Flow in cfm, Pressure in inches of water.

sections.heading: SECTION 11 — PUMP LAWS (HYDRONIC PUMP MODELING)
sections.content:
11.1 Pump Laws Flow ∝ Speed Head ∝ Speed^2 Power ∝ Speed^3

11.2 Pump Efficiency Varies with: Flow fraction Pump curve Control scheme

AI must use conservative pump law modeling.

11.3 Pump Savings PumpSaving = 1 − (Speed_new/Speed_old)^3

11.4 Differential Pressure Reset DP_new = DP_old − ΔDP Resulting in cubic power savings.

sections.heading: SECTION 12 — CHILLER MODELING (FULL ENGINEERING DETAIL)
sections.content:
12.1 Chiller Types Air-cooled Water-cooled Screw Centrifugal Magnetic bearing

AI must identify based on building size.

12.2 Chiller Efficiency (COP) COP = CoolingOutput / ElectricalInput

EER = COP × 3.412

Typical COP ranges: Air-cooled: 2.5–3.5 Water-cooled: 4.5–6.5

12.3 Lift Model Lift = CondensingTemperature − EvaporatingTemperature

Efficiency improves as lift decreases.

12.4 Chilled Water Reset Higher CHW temperature → lower lift → better COP.

Savings = CoolingLoad × (1/COP_old − 1/COP_new)

12.5 Chiller Sequencing Most plants have multiple chillers. AI must model: Lead/lag sequence Staging logic Tower optimization

12.6 Tower Optimization Tower fans modulate condenser water temperature. Lower condenser water temp reduces lift.

AI must model: CW_reset saves significant energy in water-cooled plants.

sections.heading: SECTION 13 — BOILER MODELING (THERMS OPTIMIZATION)
sections.content:
13.1 Boiler Types Fire-tube Water-tube Condensing Non-condensing Steam vs hot water

13.2 Boiler Efficiency Old boilers: 70–80% New condensing: 90–95%

13.3 Boiler Reset Logic Hot water reset: HWSP = 180°F at cold weather HWSP = 140°F at mild weather Linear reset curve reduces therms

13.4 Boiler Savings ThermSavings = HeatingLoad × (1/Eff_old − 1/Eff_new)

Condensing savings are large in mild climates.

13.5 Reheat Reduction VAV reheat reduction is a major therm measure.

AI must calculate: ReheatEnergyReduction = Δcfm_min × 1.08 × ΔT × Hours

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 14 — COOLING COIL PHYSICS & PSYCHROMETRIC MODELING
sections.content:
14.1 Purpose of Coil Modeling Cooling coil modeling enables AI to: Predict the real impact of supply air temperature reset Estimate cooling load reduction Estimate reheat load reduction Understand latent vs sensible split Detect when economizers are feasible Avoid unrealistic kWh/therm savings

14.2 Psychrometric Fundamentals Air has: Dry bulb temperature Wet bulb temperature Enthalpy Humidity ratio Relative humidity

AI must reason in terms of: Enthalpy (BTU/lb of dry air) Latent and sensible heat Mixing lines Coil entering and leaving conditions

14.3 Coil Cooling Load Cooling load = Airflow × (Enthalpy_entering − Enthalpy_leaving)

Where: Airflow in pounds of dry air per hour = cfm × 0.075 lb/ft³ × 60

AI must enforce that cooling load includes latent removal.

14.4 Sensible Heat Ratio (SHR) SHR = SensibleLoad / TotalCoolingLoad

RTUs: SHR ~ 0.75–0.90 AHUs: SHR depends on coil approach and airflow

AI must adjust SHR based on coil type.

14.5 Coil Leaving Temperature Leaving air from cooling coil normally 52–57°F. SAT reset raises leaving temperature → reduces cooling energy.

14.6 Impact of SAT Reset Raising SAT reduces coil load:

ΔCoolingLoad ≈ 1.08 × cfm × (SAT_new − SAT_old)

AI must model this directly.

14.7 Dehumidification Constraint If humidity too high, SAT reset must be limited.

AI must not apply full reset in humid climates.

14.8 Mixed-Air Calculations MixedAirTemp = OA_fraction × OutdoorTemp + RA_fraction × ReturnTemp

MixedAirEnthalpy similar formula.

14.9 Psychrometric Interaction with Economizers Using outdoor air saves mechanical cooling only if: Outdoor enthalpy < return enthalpy

AI must check enthalpy, not just dry bulb.

14.10 Coil Bypass Factor BF = fraction of air bypassing the coil Coil leaving condition: T_leaving = BF × T_enter + (1 − BF) × T_saturation

AI must include BF when calculating coil performance.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 15 — HEATING COIL PHYSICS
sections.content:
15.1 Heating Coil Load HeatingLoad = 1.08 × cfm × (SupplyTemp − MixedAirTemp)

15.2 Coil Types Hot water coils Steam coils Electric coils

AI must identify coil type from building type + gas bill.

15.3 Boiler Reset Interaction Lower hot water temperature reduces coil output → saves therms but may require increased airflow.

AI must detect: If supply is insufficient, savings must be reduced.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 16 — ECONOMIZER ENGINEERING
sections.content:
16.1 Economizer Purpose Economizers use outdoor air to supply cooling when outdoor conditions are favorable.

16.2 Economizer Logic AI must model:

If outdoor enthalpy < return enthalpy → economizer active If outdoor enthalpy > return enthalpy → economizer disabled

EconomizerSavings = Hours_ec_active × CoolingLoad_displaced

16.3 Dry-Bulb vs Enthalpy Economizers Some economizers use dry bulb only. AI must use climate zone to infer type.

16.4 Economizer Faults Most economizers fail due to: Stuck dampers Broken linkages Failed actuator Sensor error

EconomizerRetrofitSavings = Δ% of economizer hours × CoolingLoad

AI must assume 20–40% economizer availability improvement after repair.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 17 — ADVANCED RESET STRATEGIES
sections.content: 17.1 SAT Reset SAT resets upward when cooling loads are low: Typical: 55°F → 60–62°F

sections.heading: Savings: Less compressor energy Less reheat Less fan if static pressure controlled
sections.content:
17.2 CHW Reset Higher chilled-water supply temperatures improve COP.

Reset example: 44°F at high load 48–54°F at low load

Savings depend on lift reduction.

17.3 HW Reset Boiler reset curve reduces hot water temperature during mild conditions.

Setpoint example: 180°F at 20°F outdoor 140°F at 55°F outdoor

Savings primarily in therms.

17.4 Static Pressure Reset Static pressure lowered when average VAV damper positions are low.

Typical SP: Baseline: 1.5” Reset: 0.9–1.2”

Savings via affinity laws (cubic).

17.5 Ventilation Reset Ventilation reduced when occupancy low.

Savings linked to: VentilationLoad = cfm × 1.08 × (OutdoorTemp − MixedAirTemp)

AI must reduce both cooling and heating load.

17.6 Demand-Controlled Ventilation (CO2) CO2 sensors modulate ventilation.

Savings = Δcfm_vent × 1.08 × ΔT × Hours

AI must check building code minimums.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 18 — FAULT DETECTION & DIAGNOSTICS (FDD)
sections.content:
18.1 Common HVAC Faults Economizer stuck closed Economizer stuck open Failed sensors AHU short-cycling Fan belts Boiler short cycling VAV damper stuck RTU low refrigerant Compressor staging failure Static pressure set too high Minimum air too high Simultaneous heating and cooling Broken temperature sensors

18.2 FDD Savings Logic FaultRepairSavings = CoolingSavings + HeatingSavings + FanSavings

AI should assume: FaultRepairSavings = 5–15% of HVAC load Unless building-type-specific historical library suggests otherwise.

18.3 AI Fault Identification (from interval data) Economizer stuck open → winter cooling spikes Heating-cooling fighting → constant high load Fan faults → higher-than-expected night load Chiller faults → elevated summer baseline Short cycling → sawtooth pattern in interval data

AI must look for these patterns when suggesting FDD.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 19 — MULTI-MEASURE HVAC STACKING LOGIC
sections.content:
19.1 Why Stack Most HVAC savings measures interact. AI must compute combined savings without double-counting.

Example interactions: SAT reset reduces reheat Reheat reduction reduces boiler therms Economizer reduces cooling but may increase heating Fan VFD reduces cooling load when less airflow required

19.2 Savings Interaction Matrix AI must apply interaction factors:

SAT reset interacts with: Reheat reduction Fan savings CHW reset

sections.heading: Static pressure reset interacts with: Fan energy only
sections.content:
CHW reset interacts with: Cooling load Economizer dominance

HVAC scheduling interacts with: Fan load Cooling load Heating load

19.3 Combined Savings Calculation TotalSavings = Savings1 + Savings2 − InteractionPenalty

Example: SAT reset saves 10% cooling Reheat reduction saves 10% heating Combined savings NOT 20% because SAT reset reduces reheat opportunities.

AI must reduce reheat savings by typical factor (~30–50%).

19.4 HVAC + Battery Interaction Battery may reduce nighttime kWh charges but HVAC dominates daytime loads.

AI must: Ensure battery does not change baseline HVAC loads Only allow HVAC-battery synergy if DR or critical peak Avoid double-counting cooling savings from battery arbitrage

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 20 — HVAC AI GUARDRAILS (EXTENDED)
sections.content:
20.1 No Impossible Savings AI must never: Claim 40% cooling savings from SAT reset alone Claim 50% fan savings from RTU without VFD Claim 50% heating savings unless boiler replaced Claim 30% economizer savings unless climate supports Apply economizer savings in hot-humid climates inappropriately

20.2 System Identification Guardrails AI must ensure that only valid measures are applied:

No CHW reset on RTUs No boiler reset in heat pump buildings No VAV static pressure reset on CAV systems No chiller optimization in non-chiller buildings No economizer tune-up where economizer does not exist

20.3 Double Counting Guardrails AI must avoid:

Cooling + reheat double-count Fan + SAT reset overestimation Economizer + CHW reset redundant savings VFD savings + pump scheduling overlap

20.4 Safety Guardrails AI must avoid modeling measures that: Cause coil freeze risk Reduce ventilation below code minimum Overheat zones during reset Overcool zones due to economizer misapplication

20.5 Behavior Guardrails AI must: Provide ranges, not single numbers State assumptions clearly Highlight missing data Use conservative assumptions Explain interactions Warn when savings small

sections.heading: SECTION 21 — FULL HVAC MEASURE-SPECIFIC SAVINGS FORMULAS
sections.content:
21.1 Supply Air Temperature (SAT) Reset Savings SAT reset raises supply air temperature from 55°F toward 60–62°F during low load.

SATSavings = 1.08 × cfm_total × (SAT_new − SAT_old) × Hours_reset

CoolingSavings_SAT = CoolingLoad_old − CoolingLoad_new

Where: CoolingLoad_old = 1.08 × cfm × (SAT_old − ReturnAirTemp)

CoolingLoad_new = 1.08 × cfm × (SAT_new − ReturnAirTemp)

ReheatSavings_SAT = ReheatLoad_old − ReheatLoad_new

SAT reset also reduces reheat because warmer air reduces zone reheat need.

AI must: Limit SAT reset in humid climates to avoid humidity issues. Never assume full 7°F reset unless CHW and reheat allow.

21.2 Static Pressure (SP) Reset Savings Static pressure reset lowers duct pressure setpoint.

FanPower_new = FanPower_old × (SP_new/SP_old)^(3/2)

FanSavings_SP = FanPower_old − FanPower_new

AI must calculate SP savings per cubic fan law using SP measured in inches of water column.

Typical SP reset range: 1.5” → 1.0” 1.5” → 0.8” Never go below 0.6–0.8” in commercial buildings.

21.3 Chilled Water (CHW) Reset Savings Higher CHW supply temperature reduces chiller lift.

Lift_old = CondensingTemp_old − EvaporatingTemp_old Lift_new = CondensingTemp_new − EvaporatingTemp_new LiftReduction = Lift_old − Lift_new

COP_new ≈ COP_old × (Lift_old / Lift_new)

CHWSavings = CoolingLoad × (1/COP_old − 1/COP_new)

AI must enforce: CHW reset limited by humidity and coil leaving temp requirements.

21.4 Condenser Water (CW) Reset Savings Cooling tower optimization lowers condenser water temperature.

Savings_CWReset = CoolingLoad × ΔEfficiency_CW

Where: ΔEfficiency_CW = function(TowerApproachImprovement)

AI must enforce tower + chiller feasibility.

21.5 Pump VFD Savings PumpSavings = PumpPower_old − PumpPower_new Where: PumpPower_new = PumpPower_old × (Flow_new/Flow_old)^3

Flow_new = Flow_old × (Speed_new/Speed_old)

Typical reductions: 10–30% pump power savings.

21.6 Boiler Reset Savings Hot water reset reduces boiler supply temperature when outdoor air temperature is mild.

Savings_HWReset = HeatingLoad × (1/Eff_old − 1/Eff_new)

BoilerEff_new increases ~1% per 10°F reduction in hot water supply temperature.

AI must not apply reset if building requires constant high-temperature water (labs, hospitals, certain industrial zones).

21.7 Economizer Savings EconomizerSavings = Hours_with_OA_suitable × CoolingLoad_replaced

AI must compute enthalpy-based economizer suitability: OutdoorEnthalpy < ReturnEnthalpy

Typical savings: 5–20% of cooling energy depending on climate zone.

21.8 Demand-Controlled Ventilation (DCV) Savings DCV reduces outdoor air flow based on occupancy.

VentLoadReduction = Δcfm × 1.08 × (OutdoorTemp − MixedAirTemp)

CoolingSavings_DCV = VentLoadReduction during cooling mode

HeatingSavings_DCV = VentLoadReduction during heating mode / BoilerEff

AI must enforce minimum ventilation per ASHRAE 62.1.

21.9 RTU Controls Upgrade Savings Savings depend on: Improved economizer operation Better staging/sequencing Improved SAT control Night setback Fault corrections

RTUControlsSavings = 5–25% of HVAC kWh depending on condition.

AI must limit savings to realistic ranges.

21.10 RTU Replacement Savings Replacing very old RTUs improves efficiency:

CoolingSavings_RTUReplace = CoolingLoad × (1/EER_old − 1/EER_new)

HeatingSavings_RTUReplace similar using furnace efficiency.

sections.heading: SECTION 22 — ADVANCED CHILLER & BOILER RETROFIT MODELING
sections.content:

22.1 Chiller Replacement Chillers degrade 1–2% efficiency per year; older chillers may have COP < 3.5.

ReplacementCOP_new can be 5–7 (high-efficiency magnetic-bearing chillers).

Savings_ChillerReplace = CoolingLoad × (1/COP_old − 1/COP_new)

AI must confirm building has sizeable cooling loads to justify replacement.

22.2 Boiler Replacement Non-condensing boiler efficiency ~70–80% Condensing boiler efficiency ~90–95%

Savings_BoilerReplace = HeatingLoad × (1/Eff_old − 1/Eff_new)

AI must check return water temperature; condensing boilers only condense if RWT < 130°F.

22.3 Cooling Tower Optimization Tower optimization reduces lift, increasing chiller efficiency.

Savings_Tower = CoolingLoad × EfficiencyGain_from_Tower

AI must model safe wet-bulb approach.

22.4 Pump & Hydronic Reset Pump VFDs + CHW reset produce synergistic savings.

AI must ensure pump savings not double-counted against chiller reset/CHW reset interactions.

sections.heading: SECTION 25 — HVAC VALIDATION MATRIX

25.1 Purpose Ensures AI predictions are physically realistic and compliant with HVAC engineering best practices.

25.2 Validation Test Cases

Test 1 — Impossible SAT Reset If climate zone = humid, SAT reset > 3°F → fail

Test 2 — Double-Counting Cooling + Reheat If cooling savings and reheat savings exceed 30% simultaneously → fail

Test 3 — Economizer Feasibility If OA enthalpy > RA enthalpy, economizer savings > 0 → fail

Test 4 — Pump Savings Overstatement If pump savings > 40% without major retrofit → fail

Test 5 — Boiler Reset If RWT never drops below 130°F, condensing boiler savings > 5% → fail

Test 6 — VAV Fan Savings If SP reset implies >40% fan savings, flag unrealistic

Test 7 — Chiller COP Upgrade If chiller upgrade predicts >50% cooling savings → fail

Test 8 — Heating Dominated Climate If DCV heating savings < 10% in cold climate → probably low but unlikely fail If >50% → fail
